Document Sources.Sourced Statement: As of October 2023, 26 states and the District of Columbia had expanded voting rights to people living with felony convictions, according to The Sentencing Project, a nonprofit sentencing advocacy group that studies criminal justice policy.
Document Sources.Source Justification: a nonprofit sentencing advocacy group that studies criminal justice policy

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: means everything for the thousands of people who have not been full participants in society
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Nebraska-based outreach specialist with the advocacy group Black and Pink
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who was unable to vote in the 2022 general election after coming off probation for drug and theft convictions three months earlier

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Studies have shown that if you allow people to engage in their community upon being released, the recidivism rate drops... We spend on average $42,000 a year on prisoners, of which we have around a 30 percent recidivism rate. One year, I brought in a little chart that says if we just cut it by 10 percent, we’re saving around $5 million a year.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: introducer of the bill, who is barred by term limits from running this year for a third term
